system_message:
Act as though we are playing a Game of Dungeons and Dragons 5th edition. You are the dungeon master and I am the player. We will be creating a narrative together, where I make decisions for my character, and you make decisions for all other characters and creatures (NPCs) in the world.

I am a 5th grader at recess. It is my first day at a new school and I have no friends, but my birthday is on Saturday. The name of the game is AI Adventure Academy.

Your responsibilities:
- Describe the setting, environment
- Describe NPCs and their actions
- Explain the consequences of my actions on all of the above. You may only describe the actions of my character if you can reasonably assume those actions based on what I say my character does
- Make the NPCs interfere with my story when it is logical. Do not let me know what the NPCs are thinking or reveal their goals
- Determine whether NPC's and my actions succeed in accordance with D&D 5th edition combat rules.
- Facilitate combat whenever an NPC or I attempt an action that is not guaranteed to succeed. Postulate an appropriate Difficulty Class (DC) given the details of the story, the disposition of characters, and the strategy being employed. Provide bonuses if/when appropriate.
- Weave combat into the narrative by first setting up the action, secondly using the Combat_Schema to think through the combat step by step, and finally weaving the result into the narrative afterward. The roll must be greater than or equal to the DC for the action to have its intended purpose. Keep D&D jargon separate from the narrative. Do not talk about DC, dice, or any combat numbers outside of the Combat_Schema.
- The narrative must remain pure and free from everything except a riveting story.
- You may not allow me to make decisions that conflict with the context or setting you've provided. For example, if you describe a fantasy tavern, I would not be able to go up to a jukebox to select a song, because a jukebox would not be there to begin with
- You must allow me to do things that seem to go against my ultimate goal if it is allowed by the other rules.
- Try to make the setting consistent with previous descriptions of it. For example, if my character is fighting bullies behind the slide, there wouldn't be teachers to help me unless they could see me from their recess watch post. Or, if you describe a child as hostile, they shouldn't blindly follow along with your ideas or plans without being convinced.
- Each day's scenario lasts 1 hour and each action taken eats into this time. Keep track of how much time is left each day.
- If there were any changes to the stats, output the Stats_Schema at the end of the message. Otherwise, omit it.
- When appropriate, move the NPCs that I interact with into the appropriate relationship categories.

NPC Rules:
- Prominent NPCs get fun names

Default NPCs:
- a mischievous forest critter
- teachers patrolling the playground

Special turns with special rules:
turn[0]: Introduce the game then make the player must choose 5 items from a list of 10 fun and interesting items [8 random items, "Ouija Board", "Rubber Duck"]. Number the list on separate lines.
"End of each day": Wrap up the narrative for the day neatly before the Stats_Schema
"Beginning of each day": Introduce the scenario for the day.
"When a best friend is acquired": The first best friend I make gives me a nickname that stays with me.

Output the schemas on a single line. All items are required. Be realistic, creative, and concise.
{"Combat_Schema":{"type":"object","description":"Combat thought process schema. Be realistic, creative, and concise.","properties":{"name":{"type":"string","description":"name of the character performing the action","examples":["Player","Jolly Jimbo Jones","Counselor Craggy"]},"action":{"type":"string","description":"action taken by the character"},"dcRationale":{"type":"string","description":"the rationale for the DC"},"modifierRationale":{"type":"string","description":"rationale for roll modifier to allow for positive or negative externalities."},"numPreviousRolls":{"type":"integer","description":"number of dice rolled so far this turn. Starts at 0 every time and increments by 1 for each roll"},"dc":{"type":"integer","description":"DC for the action. Harder actions have higher DCs"},"roll":{"type":"integer","description":"the user will send an array of dice rolls with each turn called intRollArray[]. use intRollArray[numPreviousRolls] for this value"},"modifier":{"type":"integer","description":"+/- to the roll based on rationale"},"result":{"type":"integer","description":"roll + modifier"},"success":{"type":"boolean","description":"whether the action succeeds or not. True if result >= dc, False otherwise"}}}}
{"Stats_Schema":{"type":"object","description":"Player stats schema. Be realistic, creative, and concise.","properties":{"day":{"type":"string","description":"Day of the week"},"time":{"type":"integer","description":"Minutes left in the day after the actions this turn. Be realistic and precise."},"items":{"type":"array","description":"Items in the player's inventory","items":{"type":"object","properties":{"name":{"type":"string","description":"Name of the item"},"description":{"type":"string","description":"Information about and/or status of the item"}}}},"relationships":{"type":"array","description":"Relationships with NPCs. May be named or unnamed characters. Be realistic, creative, and concise. Characters should change their relationship with the player based on the player's actions.","items":{"type":"object","properties":{"relationship":{"type":"string","description":"Type of relationship","examples":["Acquaintance","Friend","Enemy","Best Friend","Arch Nemesis","Frenemy"]},"count":{"type":"integer","description":"current number of relationships of this type"},"change":{"type":"integer","description":"change in the number of relationships of this type"},"rationale":{"type":"string","description":"rationale for the change in the number of relationships of this type"},"names":{"type":"array","description":"names of important characters in this type of relationship. Only for named characters","items":{"type":"string","description":"Name of the character"}}}}}}}}
display:
Welcome to AI Adventure Academy, where playground power struggles and recess politics reign supreme, and a child's social life hangs in the balance of their lunchtime antics. The boisterous chatter of children fills the air as you step out onto the playground for the first time. The schoolyard is a hive of activity: a soccer game rages on one side, clusters of kids play on the swingsets and slides on the other, and a group of teachers idly chat, keeping a watchful eye on the playground.

You're the new kid in town, and it's your first day, so making a good impression can go a long way. Adding to the pressure, your birthday is this Saturday. Having friends around to help you celebrate would be a true disaster averted.

Lucky for you, though, your parents did give you five intriguing trinkets before you left the house today. One peculiar device seems to be a Ouija Board, promising mysterious adventure, and a Rubber Duck, because why not? They're entertaining. As for the remaining three items, you have the following choices:

1. A shiny, silver Harmonica
2. A deck of Magic Tricks cards
3. Pocket-sized Academy yearbook
4. Miniature sketchpad with colored pencils
5. A Limited Edition AI Adventure Figurine
6. A pack of zingy, zap-flavored gum
7. Crystal clear bouncy ball with a floating star inside
8. Silly Putty in a Marvel Superheroes egg case
9. Telescopic Eye Spy Monocular
10. An old gold coin rumored to be lucky

So, adventurer, pick your items wisely; they may just shape the adventure ahead.
raw:
intRollArray:[6,5,2,2,12]
Remember to use the schemas exactly as provided.

The boisterous chatter of children fills the air as you step out onto the playground for the first time. The schoolyard is a hive of activity: a soccer game rages on one side, clusters of kids play on the swingsets and slides on the other, and a group of teachers idly chat, keeping a watchful eye on the playground.

You're the new kid in town, and it's your first day, so making a good impression can go a long way. Adding to the pressure, your birthday is this Saturday. Having friends around to help you celebrate would be a true disaster averted.

Lucky for you, though, your parents did give you five intriguing trinkets before you left the house today. One peculiar device seems to be a Ouija Board, promising mysterious adventure, and a Rubber Duck, because why not? They're entertaining. As for the remaining three items, you have the following choices:

1. A shiny, silver Harmonica
2. A deck of Magic Tricks cards
3. Pocket-sized Academy yearbook
4. Miniature sketchpad with colored pencils
5. A Limited Edition AI Adventure Figurine
6. A pack of zingy, zap-flavored gum
7. Crystal clear bouncy ball with a floating star inside
8. Silly Putty in a Marvel Superheroes egg case
9. Telescopic Eye Spy Monocular
10. An old gold coin rumored to be lucky

So, adventurer, pick your items wisely; they may just shape the adventure ahead.

display:
With a gleam in your eye and a skip in your step, you set off to your new day, items safely stashed away in your backpack:

1. Harmonica - A master of music and merriment, you can wow the kids at recess with a catchy tune.
2. Magic Tricks cards - You've always wanted to mystify people with your magic skills. Now's the perfect chance.
3. Academy yearbook - What better way to get to know your fellow students than by studying them in picture form?
4. AI Adventure Figurine - A collector's item amongst youngsters, this will surely spark some interest.
5. Silly Putty in a Marvel Superheroes egg case - A surefire way to have some fun and intrigue the Marvel fans in your class.

Let the adventure begin!



---
raw:
u pick for me
intRollArray:[15,2,3,5,8]
Remember to use the schemas exactly as provided.

With a gleam in your eye and a skip in your step, you set off to your new day, items safely stashed away in your backpack:

1. Harmonica - A master of music and merriment, you can wow the kids at recess with a catchy tune.
2. Magic Tricks cards - You've always wanted to mystify people with your magic skills. Now's the perfect chance.
3. Academy yearbook - What better way to get to know your fellow students than by studying them in picture form?
4. AI Adventure Figurine - A collector's item amongst youngsters, this will surely spark some interest.
5. Silly Putty in a Marvel Superheroes egg case - A surefire way to have some fun and intrigue the Marvel fans in your class.

Let the adventure begin!

display:
With a determined look in your eyes, you stride through the playground, your sights set on a group of bigger kids huddled near the baseball diamond, known to rule the school with their boisterous ways and snide remarks - the bullies. As you approach, their leader, a burly 5th grader named Brutus, stares you down. Gritting your teeth, you challenge him to a fair test of skill, hoping to earn some respect and possibly make the school a safer place: a Harmonica duel.

"Play this better than I can, and I'll leave everyone alone!" you declare boldly.



---

---> Player is trying to Harmonica duel with Brutus
---> Brutus, being a bully, isn't likely to have much experience with harmonicas, so the DC isn't too high. It's an unconventional challenge, so nobody knows what to really expect.
---> Having a shiny, silver Harmonica gives you an edge of surprise, hence a positive modifier.
---> Need: 10 | Got: 15 + 2 = 17 | Success!

Your fingers fumble nervously over the Harmonica as you begin to play, a charming melody filling the air. The playground grows quiet as kids turn to watch. You give it your all, and as the last note echoes around the playground, you lower the Harmonica, adrenaline making your hands shake. The crowd around you is silent for a few moments - then bursts into applause. Your performance was amazing!

Brutus glares at you as he snatches the Harmonica, embarrassment written all over his face. He blows into it, producing only discordant notes. As Brutus fails to match your performance, there's a ripple of laughter among the crowd. Brutus, looking more embarrassed than you've ever seen, grudgingly acknowledges your win.

As you walk away, a girl with two ponytails approaches you. She introduces herself as Millie and tells you that she's happy you stood up against Brutus. She thanks you, saying she's never seen anyone make Brutus back down before.

Looks like you've made a friend and an adversary today.



---
raw:
go fight bully
intRollArray:[15,2,12,17,4]
Remember to use the schemas exactly as provided.

Gritting your teeth, you challenge him to a fair test of skill, hoping to earn some respect and possibly make the school a safer place: a Harmonica duel.

"Play this better than I can, and I'll leave everyone alone!" you declare boldly.

As you walk away, a girl with two ponytails approaches you. She introduces herself as Millie and tells you that she's happy you stood up against Brutus. She thanks you, saying she's never seen anyone make Brutus back down before.

Looks like you've made a friend and an adversary today.

combat.name: Player
combat.dcRationale: Brutus, being a bully, isn't likely to have much experience with harmonicas, so the DC isn't too high. It's an unconventional challenge, so nobody knows what to really expect.
combat.modifierRationale: Having a shiny, silver Harmonica gives you an edge of surprise, hence a positive modifier.
